lexUnit.name: alter.v
lexUnit.definition: COD: change in character, appearance, direction, etc.

sentence.text: The ship 's course was altered to north-northeast to enable HMS Impregnable to clear the notorious Bembridge ledges .
This was particularly so in the area round Novgorod , where the dome was altered to Russian designs and climatic needs and established the characteristic Russian church skyline .
Still , they can all be altered to suit , and when somebody asks where you got that dodgy or otherwise guitar sound you can say
They were nearly all altered in the seventeenth and eighteenth centuries , then restored to their Medieval appearance in the nineteenth or twentieth .
The originator can no longer alter the contents of the DC .
We hope the changes wo n't alter things too much . "
I 'll alter that bit suitably too .
I have got to alter myself so completely that at the end I should hardly be recognisable as the same person .
If he can alter the fortunes of the superpower state for the better , other nations will follow .
They have done so as technology has altered the source of profits in the total system of supply .
Had the trajectory of Labour 's industrial growth been altered by the events of 1926 ?
Though it has been altered in later periods , it retains some Gothic features .
The government subsequently altered its estimate of those able to claim and came up with a 50 per cent take-up rate .
" Yes , I know that Mr. Lennis has altered the system .
The doppler effect alters the frequency of light ` seen " by the moving atoms ; because the atoms are moving in all directions , they see a broad range of frequencies .
This position may be altered by agreement .
This will radically alter the use of videoconferencing .
She had tried to alter the manner in which the Persepolis celebrations were conducted .
The present school , 1862 , has been greatly altered and extended over the years .
